title-group.article-title: Attitude control of miniature spacecraft under the gravitational effect using a hub-bimorph mechanism

abstract.p: This paper presents the attitude control of miniature spacecraft using a hub-bimorph mechanism, which is simplified from a so-called pseudowheel. A nonlinear mathematical model for the spacecraft coupled by the hub-bimorph mechanism is developed. The proposed model includes not only the inverse piezoelectric effect of the mechanism but also the gravitational effect. This paper also presents three controller designs – the pole assignment method, the linear quadratic regulator, and the time-delay control – which demonstrate the feasibility of spacecraft attitude control using the hub-bimorph mechanism.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Attitude dynamics and control of spacecraft are extremely important for a successful completion of a space mission. There have been numerous researches devoted to attitude dynamics and control of spacecraft over the past few decades (Kaplan, 1976; Wertz, 1980; Hughes, 2004), and many researchers have applied various control theories to attitude stabilization and control, such as optimal control, sliding mode control, feedback linearization, nonlinear feedback control, etc. (Suleman, 2004; Urakubo et al., 2004; Hu and Ma, 2006). Over the last two decades, miniature spacecrafts, including pico-spacecraft and femto-spacecraft, were considered to be the next logical step in the evolution of capable, low-cost spacecraft systems (Haag et al, 1999; Smith, 2000). Since these spacecrafts are very small in size and weight, they pose unique engineering challenges. The micro-/nano-technologies can be one of the major solutions for the challenges (Reiter et al., 1998; Cass, 2001). However, these low cost, low mass, and low power devices, such as MEMS gyros, MEMS accelerometers, and MEMS digital thrusters, limited space applications.

Moulton and Anathasuresh (2001) considered a MEMS actuator based on an electrothermal compliant (ETC) mechanism. The ETC mechanism works on the principle of non-uniform Joule heating of various sections of the actuator to generate deflections. The amount of deflection is controlled by the applied voltage while the direction of deflection is regulated by changing the electrical connection from series to parallel or vice versa. Li et al. (2001) examined a MEMS actuator, known as a pseudowheel and shown in Figure 1, for attitude stabilizations of spacecrafts. This actuator comprises multiple small beams (see Figure 2) attached to the hub, and each beam is made of two different electro-thermal materials of unequal thermal expansion coefficients. Using the bi-metallic or bimorph effect, when a voltage is applied on these beams, they undergo deformations due to thermal expansion (Jonsmann et al., 1999). Thus, when an external voltage is applied to the bimorph, it bends and the hub produces a counter-direction rotation due to the conservation of momentum. Therefore, the rotation motion can be regulated by switching the external voltage, so the actuation is bounded and fully reversed. Furthermore, the issues of controllability and developed motion planning algorithms for such a system were discussed, and the approximate methods were used to develop two algorithms for controlling satellite orientation (Koh et al., 2002a,b). Kuo et al. (2008) employed the inverse kinematics and developed an algorithm to determine the optimal trajectory by minimizing the actuating energy. Figure 1.
A MENS actuator – a pseudowheel.
Figure 2.
Illustration of laminate beams on a MEMS actuator (arrows represent the polarization directions).

The aforementioned researchers have investigated the feasibility of the pseudowheel applied to attitude control of spacecraft. However, most of them assumed the pseudowheel as a rigid hub hinged by multiple rigid links. (The link should be modeled as a bimorph.) When an external voltage is applied, the links perform a rigid body rotation, which rotates the spacecraft. Due to the flexibility of the bimorph, its inverse piezoelectric effect should be taken into account in the spacecraft-pseudowheel system. In this paper, the pseudowheel is simplified as a hub-bimorph mechanism, and the proposed mathematical model includes the spacecraft attitude dynamics, the earth’s gravity-gradient effect, and the inverse piezoelectric effect of the mechanism. This paper also presents three controllers – the pole assignment method, the linear quadratic regulator, and the time-delay control – which demonstrate the feasibility of spacecraft attitude control using the hub-bimorph mechanism. This paper is organized as follows: Section 2 presents a nonlinear spacecraft-actuator model, where the actuator is a hub-bimoprh mechanism. Section 3 presents the dynamic analysis, which investigates the system parameters and provides the system design basis. Section 4 demonstrates numerical simulations, which have a constant external voltage as an input signal. Section 5 provides three controllers to suppress the vibration of the system. Section 6 summarizes some significant study results.

sec.title: 2. Spacecraft attitude dynamics coupled with a hub-bimorph mechanism
sec.p:
A spacecraft is assumed as a rigid body. The pitch motion is controlled by a hub-bimorph mechanism, where the hub is fixed on the mass center of the spacecraft, and the bimorph is assumed with small flexible longitudinal and transverse deformations. A voltage is applied to the bimorph to produce an elastic deformation, whose inertial force will actuate the spacecraft attitude motion. A hub-bimorph mechanism is illustrated in Figure 3, and there are three sets of coordinate systems defined in Figure 4. The pair (X0,Z0) represents the reference coordinate, and (X1,Z1) is the spacecraft body-fixed coordinate. The vector R→ is from the earth center to the mass center of the spacecraft, and the angle α is from the X0 axis to the vector R→. Angle θ represents the pitch angle of the spacecraft. Based on these assumptions, the rigid body motion of the spacecraft and the elastic motion of the hub-bimorph mechanism are coupled, so the governing equations of the system are nonlinear. Figure 3.
A hub-bimorph mechanism.
Figure 4.
A miniature spacecraft with a hub-bimorph mechanism.

To investigate the dynamics of the spacecraft and the hub-bimorph mechanism, the Euler-Lagrange equation to formulate the governing equations is applied, and the Lagrangian is written as (1)L=T-U-W where T, U and W are respectively the kinetic energy, the potential energy and the work, and they will be formulated as follows.

I. Kinetic energy: (2)T=12(Ms+Mh)→·R·→·R+12(Isy+Ih)(α·+θ·)2 +12∫0 lρA(→·R+→·r)·(→·R+→·r)dx where the first two terms respectively represent the rigid body motion of the spacecraft and the hub, and the last term is the kinetic energy of the bimorph. Quantities Ms and Mh are the masses of the spacecraft and the hub, respectively; Isy and Ih are the moments of inertia of the spacecraft and the bimorph with respect to the Y-axis, respectively; ρA is the product of the density and the cross-section area of the bimorph; r→ is a position vector of an arbitrary point on the bimorph from the mass center of the spacecraft; l is the length of the bimorph.

sec.title: 3. Dynamic analysis
sec.p:
In this section, the gravity-gradient effect is neglected, and the steady state can be reached by adding a proportional damper into the governing equations. When an external voltage is applied to the bimorph, an initial torque can be generated to vibrate the spacecraft. After reaching the steady state, the torque will vanish, and the spacecraft will perform a rigid body rotation. Based on equation (7), the steady-state rotating angle of the spacecraft and the initial torque are respectively given as (19)θss=-F1 TK0 -1F0/I0
(20)Tq0=-F1 T(M0-F1F1 T/I0)-1F0 where (21)I0=Ih+Ib+Isy

In order to perform the best regulation of the rotating angle of the spacecraft, it is necessary to analyze the geometry parameters and the bimorph materials.
Bimorph materials: Two kinds of piezoelectric materials, PZT and PVDF, are compared. Table 1 lists the rotating angle of spacecraft and the initial torque generated by the hub-bimorph mechanism based on PZT and PVDF bimorphs. To compare their material parameters, PZT is stiffer than PVDF, and the piezoelectric constant of PZT is higher than that of PVDF. Based on equations (19) and (20), the steady-state rotating angle and the initial torque using PZT are larger than those using PVDF.
Piezoelectric composites: The bimorph can be redesigned as a composite sandwich structure, shown in Figure 5. Young’s modulus and the density of the core materials are assumed as 102 GN/m2 and 8874 Kg/m3, respectively. Both values are much larger than those of PZT and PVDF. Figure 6 shows the rotating angle and the initial torque as functions of the ratio of the thickness of the core materials to that of the piezoelectric materials (hc/hp). The result shows that the rotating angle decreases as the ratio increases, and the initial torque decreases as the ratio increases.
Number of bimorph layers: Figure 7 shows a hub-bimorph mechanism with multiple layers of piezoelectric materials. Figure 8 shows the rotating angle and the initial torque as functions of the number of layers. The results show that the rotating angle decreases as the number of layers increases, and the initial torque decreases as the number of layers increases.
Number of bimorphs: In order to increase the torque generated by the hub-bimorph mechanism, an alternative design is a hub attached with multiple bimorphs shown in Figure 9. As expected, the rotating angle and the initial torque increase as the number of bimorphs increases. The results are shown in Figure 10.

sec.title: 4. Numerical simulation
sec.p:
A miniature spacecraft is assumed to move around the earth on a circular orbit, and the altitude is 1000 km. Thus, the orbital rate, 9.9623 × 10−4 rad/s, will produce a longitudinal displacement at steady state. Based on equation (3), a gravity-gradient torque will appear in the governing equations when the moments of inertia of the spacecraft on the X1- and Z1-axes are not equal. An external constant voltage 100 volt is applied to the bimorph made of the PZT materials, and the bimorph produces the flexible deformation and the torque, which rotates the spacecraft. The governing equations shown in equation (7) are solved by using the AMM, where two and four modes are selected to approximate the longitudinal and transverse deformations, respectively. In addition, a proportional damper is added into the governing equation to simulate the physical damper, which can decay the bimorph vibrations. Figures 11 and 12 show the tip longitudinal and transverse displacements of the bimorph, respectively. Figure 13 shows the torque generated by the bimorph, and Figure 14 shows the rotating angle of the miniature spacecraft, respectively. Figure 11.

By linearizing the governing equations, the oscillation frequency due to the earth’s gravity can be expressed as (22)ωg=3μ(Isz-Isx)R3I0

Equation 22 shows that the oscillation frequency is proportional to the square root of the ratio of moment of inertia. The ratio (Isz-Isx)/I0 is assigned as 10 in order to show a vibration with a higher vibration frequency, and Figure 15 shows the time response of the rotating angle of the hub due to the earth’s gravity at steady state. sec.title: 5. Vibration suppression
sec.p:
The modes of the entire system can be divided into three categories: two of them are from the longitudinal and transverse motions of the bimorph, and the other one is from the rotating motion of the spacecraft due to the gravity-gradient effect. Based on the aforementioned assumptions, the natural frequencies of the three categories are listed in Table 2. To validate the attitude control by using the hub-bimorph mechanism, a regulation problem is performed and an impulse input is considered. The system is regulated by individually applying three controllers: the pole assignment method, the linear quadratic regulator, and the time-delay control. The controller design is based on a linearized system in terms of the rotating mode of the spacecraft and the first two modes of the bimorph’s transverse deflection. The responses of the rotating motion of the spacecraft using the three controllers are shown in Figure 16, and the corresponding control signals are shown in Figure 17. Figure 16.

I. Pole assignment method (PSM)

For a linear system, the PSM arbitrarily assigns the locations of the poles by solving the following equation for the state feedback gain KPSM (Kautsky et al., 1985). (23)det(sI-Al+BlKPSM)=r(s) where Al and Bl are the matrices in the linear state equations x·=Alx+Blu, and r(s) is a characteristic polynomial in terms of the poles of the closed-loop system. Based on Table 2, it is noted that the rotating motion of the spacecraft and the transverse deflection of the bimorph dominate the system. To obtain a fast decayed response, one imposes high damping ratios (ξ=0.9) into the rotating mode and the first two modes of the transverse deflection of the bimorph to design the state feedback gain. Figure 16 shows that the PSM controller provides a great vibration reduction due to the selection of the high damping ratio, but the settling time is about 250 seconds. It is possible to reduce the settling time, but it would increase the vibration at the transient state.
II. Linear quadratic regulator (LQR)

To apply the LQR, an objective function is performed, as per Anderson and Moore (1990) (24)J=12∫0 ∞[xTQx+uTRu]dt where the weighting matrices Q and R are selected as Q=100I (I is an identity matrix) and R=10-8. The optimal control problem leads to the state feedback gain (KLQG=R-1BTP) can be obtained by solving the algebraic Riccati equation (25)PA+ATP+Q-PBR-1BTP=0

To compare the results using the three controllers, the LQR controller produces the smallest vibration at the transient state, but it requires the largest initial applied voltage. In addition, the LQR controller still produces a slight vibration at the steady state.
III. Time-delay control (TDC)

The time-delay control can be a prefilter, which can effectively reduce the overshoot of the bimorph vibration (Kuo, 1999). A simple time-delay controller in Laplace transform is given as A0+e-sT0, where A0 and T0 should be determined in order to eliminate the poles of the system. The form A0+e-sT0 can cancel only one pair of poles, so it is feasible to expand the controller to multi-mode systems. For the transient response, the dominant modes come from the transverse motion of the bimorph, so the time-delay control is applied to reduce the vibration by eliminating the first two modes. For the steady-state response, the rotating mode affects the system. One considers the rotating mode and the first two modes of the bimorph’s transverse deflection to the design of the time-delay controller. Thus, there are seven time-delay functions included in the controllers, whose delay time occurs at 0.0161, 0.0461, 0.0622, 85.6958, 85.7259, and 85.7419 seconds. The top graph in Figure 17 shows the first three time-delays (labeled as three arrows). Thus, the system approaches the steady state after 85.7419 seconds.

sec.title: 6. Conclusions
sec.p: The pseudowheel has been validated as an actuator of attitude control of miniature spacecraft in the literature. All related research assumed the pseudowheel as a rigid body, i.e. a hub hinged by some bimorphs. This paper takes into account the inverse piezoelectric effect of the pseudowheel, and a nonlinear mathematical model of a spacecraft-actuator system is proposed, which is composed of the spacecraft attitude dynamics, the earth’s gravity-gradient effect, and the dynamics of the hub-bimorph mechanism. The model not only has a low frequency mode due to the gravity-gradient effect but also has high frequency modes from the transverse and longitudinal deflections of the bimorphs. Further, this paper also performs dynamic analysis and numerical simulations, which study the influences of the system parameters. Finally, this paper applies three controllers to fulfill the vibration suppressions, and the results show that the attitude control of miniature spacecraft can be achieved by applying the hub-bimorph mechanism and the controllers.
